data.title: Sylvia Anderson
data.meta_description: If Lady Penelope, the diminutive star of Thunderbirds and saviour of humanity on a weekly basis, was one of the most iconic women of the 1960s, then Sylvia Anderson should get most of the credit.
data.text:
If Lady Penelope, the diminutive star of Thunderbirds and saviour of humanity on a weekly basis, was one of the most iconic women of the 1960s, then Sylvia Anderson should get most of the credit.

Anderson, who along with her then husband Gerry found international success with the puppet-powered television adventure series, was the inspiration, co-creator and voice of Lady Penelope. It is fair to say that Thunderbirds had a cultural impact on 1960s Britain to rival that of the Beatles, the Mini Cooper and Mary Quant.

Initially employed to make tea and do the filing for a shambolic and disorganised production company, Anderson graduated to key creative roles and became widely regarded as the first lady of sci-fi. Her legions of fans included celebrities
